title: Mount Warburton Pike
text:
Mount Warburton Pike is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> on <a href="Saturna%20Island">Saturna Island</a> in the <a href="Gulf%20Islands">Gulf Islands</a> of <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. It is the highest summit in the Gulf Islands, other than <a href="Saltspring%20Island">Saltspring Island</a>, and is part of the <a href="Gulf%20Islands%20National%20Park%20Reserve">Gulf Islands National Park Reserve</a>.
Name origin.
The mountain is named for <a href="Warburton%20Pike">Warburton Pike</a> (1861–1915), who <a href="alienated%20land">alienated land</a> on Saturna in 1886 and whose ranch included the mountain. Pike was an explorer, sportsman and author and wrote a book on his experiences in the Canadian North, "The Barren Ground of Northern Canada". Pike's death was untimely and tragic. After returning to Britain to enlist for <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> and, being refused because he was too old, died by suicide. The summit and a rock in <a href="Active%20Pass">Active Pass</a> were named for him, and a memorial was erected at <a href="Porter%20Landing">Porter Landing</a> in the <a href="Dease%20Lake%20%28British%20Columbia%29">Dease Lake</a> region, where he had ventured in his years in B.C. The monument was donated by his friends <a href="Osborne%20Beauclerk%2C%2012th%20Duke%20of%20St%20Albans">Osborne Beauclerk, 12th Duke of St Albans</a> and <a href="Marshall%20Latham%20Bond">Marshall Latham Bond</a>.
